EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

2009 RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN RESUBMITTAL


ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

At Solutia's Indian Orchard Plant, we are committed to operating and maintaining all of our processes, especially those using hazardous substances, in a safe and responsible manner.  We use a combination of accidental release prevention programs, process safety management systems, and emergency response planning to help ensure the safety and health of our employees, the public, and the environment.  This Executive Summary provides an overview of the comprehensive risk management and process safety procedures and practices that we have designed and implemented at the Indian Orchard Plant and includes information on the following:

-  A description of our facility and the use of substances regulated by the EPA's Risk Management Program (RMP) Rule.
-  An overview of our accidental release prevention programs.
-  A five-year accident history for accidental releases of chemicals regulated by the RMP rule.
-  An overview of our emergency response programs
-  An overview of planned improvements at the facility to help prevent accidental chemical releases from occurring and adversely affecting our employees, the surrounding community, or the environment.


FACILITY (STATIONARY SOURCE) DESCRIPTION

The Indian Orchard Plant was originally established by the Fiberloid Corporation in 1904 and purchased by Monsanto Company in 1938.  In 1963, Monsanto acquired the Shawinigan Resins facility on the opposite side of Grochmal Avenue, creating the current site.  The plant took the Indian Orchard name in 1982 and following a spin-off from Monsanto in 1997, Solutia Inc. was formed.  The site includes manufacturing units producing high-value specialty products that include Saflex interlayer, Gelva adhesives, Butvar resin, and Resimene coatings.  The site also includes a Technical Center, complete with research laboratories and pilot plant facilities, finished product

warehouse buildings, wastewater collection and neutralization facilities, a powerhouse, analytical laboratories, and office buildings.  In addition, IneosNOVA and MassPower own and operate facilities within the borders of the Indian Orchard site.  Under current site operations, the Resimenes Department, and all associated assets, is owned by Ineos Melamines and the Adhesives Department, and all associated assets, is owned by Cytec Industries, Inc.  However, the processes in both of these departments continue to be operated and maintained by Solutia employees, they are included in SolutiaA?s process safety management programs, and they have been reported in this Risk Management Plan.  The entire plant occupies approximately 250 acres and Solutia currently employs approximately 460 people from the greater Springfield area and surrounding communities.  Additional employees for IneosNOVA, MassPower, Ineos Melamines, and Cytec Industries also work at the site.  


REGULATED SUBSTANCES

In our current production processes, we use two chemicals that the EPA has identified as having the potential to cause significant offsite consequences in the event of a substantial accidental release:

Vinyl Acetate Monomer (VAM)

Vinyl acetate monomer is shipped by our suppliers as a liquid in approved railcars.  An average of 3 railcars are typically present at the site at any given time, however, a maximum of 5 railcars may be stored at the site to support plant operations.  These railcars are unloaded into an aboveground storage tank that has a capacity of approximately 200,000 gallons and is filled to 80% capacity or 160,000 gallons.  This tank is located inside a concrete containment structure designed to hold the entire contents of the tank in the event of an accidental release.  The facilityA?s Adhesives Department uses vinyl acetate in the production of numerous gelva adhesive products for various applications while our South Butvar Department utilizes vinyl acetate as a key raw

material in the production of polyvinyl butyral or A?PVBA? resin.  This resin is a primary ingredient in the manufacture of a plastic sheet (interlayer) that is A?sandwichedA? in laminated safety glass for automotive and architectural applications.  Significantly smaller A?Day TanksA? of approximately 5,000 gallons capacity are utilized in each department to support daily production needs.

Formaldehyde

Formaldehyde in an aqueous (water-based) solution, also called A?FormalinA?, is shipped to the site by our suppliers in approved tank trucks that are unloaded upon arrival into one of two bulk storage tanks.  One tank has a capacity of 83,000 gallons and can be filled to a maximum volume of 80,000 gallons while the other has a capacity of 35,000 gallons and a maximum fill volume of approximately 33,000 gallons.  Under current plant operations, the smaller tank is not being used.  An additional A?Day TankA? of approximately 7,000 gallons capacity is utilized in the process area to support daily production needs.  The inventory of Formalin is used exclusively by the Resimenes Department of the Indian Orchard Plant in the production of metal coatings used in automotive paints and other industrial applications. 

Our accidental release prevention programs and our contingency planning efforts help us effectively manage the potential hazards that are posed to our employees, the public, and the environment by our use of these chemicals 


GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

We take a systematic and proactive approach to preventing accidental releases of hazardous chemicals at our facility.  Our process safety management and risk management systems include each of the key components of a successful prevention program including:

 * Development and maintenance of process safety information
 * Completion and revalidation of process hazards analysis (PHA) studies 
 * Development, review, and use of written operating procedures

* Development and administration of employee training programs
 * Mechanical integrity programs for plant equipment
 * Management of change procedures for new or modified equipment, process conditions, etc.
 * Execution of pre-startup safety reviews
 * Completion of program compliance audits
 * Incident investigations for injuries, spills, fires, and near misses
 * Employee participation in all elements of our process safety and prevention programs
 * Implementation of hot work permitting requirements
 * Evaluation, qualification, and management of contractors utilized at the site

As part of our prevention efforts, we have also implemented the following chemical-specific prevention steps:
 
DESIGNING for Safety:

-  Corporate engineering standards established for the design, construction, and installation of process equipment and related systems based on recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices.
-  Tanks, vessels, and piping designed, constructed, and tested in accordance with American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME) and American Petroleum Institute (API) codes and standards.
-  All systems and components designed to meet or exceed government standards.
-  Hazardous area classifications determined for electrical installations and equipment in or near process areas
-  Computer-based process control systems that continuously monitor process parameters, provide warning alarms, and take actions when necessary, to prevent process deviations that could lead to a chemical release.
-  Secondary containment structures installed around all storage tanks.  The containment structures surrounding the Formalin storage tanks are also completely covered to minimize vapor migration in the event of a release.
-  Sprinkler systems, deluge systems, and fixed fire monitors installed throughout the plant.  These systems are inspected, tested, and maintained in accordance with National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) codes and standards.
-  Containment str

uctures and collection systems installed for loading and unloading of railcars and tank trucks.
-  Safety-critical systems designed to A?fail safeA? during a loss of utilities
-  Use of instrumented protective systems and alarms for critical process control systems.
-  Multiple layers of protection for all safety critical systems and/or operations.

MAINTAINING our Plant:

-  Inspection, testing, and preventive maintenance tasks scheduled and conducted in accordance with recognized industry codes and standards, manufacturerA?s recommendations, and operating experience.
- Written mechanical integrity procedures developed and implemented to specify site requirements
-  Process and equipment maintenance performed by highly-skilled and trained plant mechanics.
-  Inspection and testing of tanks, pressure vessels, and piping includes use of non-destructive methods such as hydrostatic pressure testing, ultrasonic thickness testing, radiography (x-ray), and dye penetrant testing, among others.
-A? Inspection, testing, and preventive maintenance tasks are scheduled and tracked by a computer-based system that automatically produces work orders for activities that are due for completion.

OPERATING Safely:

-  All site operations are continuously monitored and controlled by computer systems that automatically shutdown equipment and systems to preserve safety.
-  Process control rooms are continually staffed to monitor operating conditions and provide immediate response to process deviations.
-A? All process operators are trained and tested on the operating procedures and safe work practices required for their department including annual refresher training.
-  Each manufacturing department has developed process-specific operating procedures (SOPA?s), work instructions, and standard operating conditions (SOCA?s) documents, which address all process operations including normal operations, emergency operations, and emergency shutdown.
-  Written operating procedures and supportin

g documents are developed, maintained, and reviewed in accordance with OSHA, EPA and Solutia company requirements.
-A? The inventories of chemicals on-site are minimized, where possible, to reduce risk while satisfying manufacturing needs.
-  Random drug testing is conducted for all plant personnel performing safety-critical functions at the site.

AUDITING our Operations:

-  Site awarded A?Responsible Care 14001A? certification in October 2007 following two certification audits.  Surveillance audits conducted in April 2008 and November 2008 by outside parties.  Next audit scheduled for November 2009.  Internal compliance audits are conducted quarterly by site ESHS staff.
-  Site awarded A?OSHA StarA? in 1997.  Voluntary Protection Program Audits conducted by outside parties in 1997, 2000, and 2005.  Next audit will be conducted in 2010.
-  Compliance audits of the process safety management and risk management prevention programs conducted at least every three years.
-  Comprehensive audits of safety, health, industrial hygiene, property protection, and occupational medicine conducted by Solutia Corporate ESH every three to four years.  Most recent conducted in June 2007.
-A? Routine external audits conducted by OSHA, EPA, U.S. Department of Transportation, and Massachusetts Department of Environmental Protection.
-A? Corporate environmental compliance audits conducted every five years.  Most recent conducted in September 2006.
-  Environmental self-audits conducted and documented by ESHS staff monthly.
-A? Process hazards analysis studies conducted for each covered process by multi-disciplined teams at least once every 5 years and more frequently for major project modifications and process expansions.
-A? Audits of all 4 permitted processes (Breaking into Process, Confined Space Entry, Lockout/Tagout, and Hot Work) are conducted throughout the plant every month, throughout the course of each month, by a designated team consisting of 42 personnel from department su

pervision, ESHS, and plant management.  Audit results are documented, compiled, and reported to identify areas for improvement.
-A? Chemical spills, injuries, fires, security incidents, near misses and other events are reported and investigated.

These individual elements of our prevention program work together to prevent accidental chemical releases.  Our company and our employees are committed to the standard that these management systems set for the way we do business, and we have specific accountabilities and controls to ensure that we are meeting our own high standards for accident prevention.


FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

Since our previous plan submittal in June 2004, there have been no accidental releases from our RMP covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage at the site.  In addition, there have been no incidents resulting in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.


EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAMS

We maintain an integrated contingency plan, which consolidates all of the various federal, state, and local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning.  Our program provides the essential procedures and training for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.  Furthermore, we coordinate our facility emergency response procedures with the community emergency response plan.

Training and Preparation:
-  Emergency Response Teams established at the site including Fire Brigade, Hazardous Materials Response Team, and Medical First Responders.  Training and drills include advanced interior and exterior structural fire fighting, hazardous materials control and containment, confined space and technical rescue, first aid, CPR, and use of automated electronic defibrillator (AED).
-  Dedicated plant Fire Truck, Hazardous Materials Response Truck, and supplementary HazMat Trailer staged at the plant Fire House.
-  A

dditional emergency and spill response equipment staged throughout the plant for immediate use.
-  Specialized teams and technical specialists dedicated to off-site response for hazardous material transportation emergencies.
-  Personnel in chemical manufacturing departments are trained in emergency shutdown procedures.
-  Members of Springfield Fire Department and the Emergency Preparedness group tour the site and our operations on a periodic basis.
-  Solutia Fire Brigade training and drills conducted periodically with municipal fire, police and ambulance crews.
-  Site maintains active participation on the City of Springfield Local Emergency Planning Committee. 

Chemical Release Response:
-  Department operators proceed to shutdown and isolate the affected system.
-  Emergency Response Teams alerted and dispatched through plant Guard House staffed 24/7/365.
-  Plant Fire Truck and Hazardous Materials Truck dispatched to the scene.
-  Pre-planned drill scenarios for chemical releases put into action.
-  Site Environmental, Safety, Health, and Security personnel alerted and dispatched.
-  Springfield Fire and Police Departments and LEPC contacted to activate city emergency plan, if necessary.

Community Emergency Response:
-  Once notified by Solutia, Springfield Emergency Management System notifies local public safety officials.
-  Local law enforcement and fire departments will alert community via public address speakers, radio, television, and/or door-to-door notification and will advise whether to shelter-in-place or evacuate, if necessary.
-  Affected personnel will follow emergency procedures.


PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

SolutiaA?s Indian Orchard Plant is committed to the principals of continuous improvement in all areas of safety.  This is key to our participation in OSHAA?s Voluntary Protection Program and the American Chemistry CouncilA?s Responsible Care Program.  Our plant is constantly upgrading its operations and safety systems to improve the

level of protection to our employees, the community, and the environment we operate in.

To foster continuous improvement in the elements of process safety and risk management, the plant hired a dedicated Process Safety Lead in March 2007.  His primary responsibilities include implementation of SolutiaA?s corporate process safety and risk management requirements and initiatives as well as enhancement of the existing programs at the site.  Our Process Safety Lead functions as the Indian Orchard Plant representative on SolutiaA?s company-wide Process Safety Core Team, Facility Siting Task Force, and Management of Change Team.  A great deal of progress has been made in the continuous improvement of the process safety and risk management systems at the Indian Orchard Plant, and within Solutia as a whole, during the last two years.  Some examples of these improvements include, but are not limited to, the following:

Facility Siting:  SolutiaA?s Facility Siting Task Force developed and issued the final version of the Solutia Corporate Facility Siting Procedure in 2008.  This document specifies the requirements for evaluating and controlling the potential risks to personnel in permanent, portable, and temporary buildings at all Solutia-owned sites worldwide.  During the course of 2008 and 2009 thus far, several tasks related to facility siting were conducted by the Indian Orchard Plant including: building occupancy surveys; portable and temporary building inventories; development of dust explosion and toxic release scenarios; and initial facility siting evaluations of all Solutia operations at the facility.

Compliance Auditing:  SolutiaA?s Process Safety Core Team made several improvements to the companyA?s compliance auditing program for process safety and risk management over the last year including a complete revision of the audit methodology, staffing requirements, and checklists to be used by all U.S. sites when conducting process safety management and/or risk manag

ement program compliance audits.

Process Hazard Analysis (PHA):  SolutiaA?s company-wide Process Safety Core Team made several improvements to the risk ranking scheme and associated matrix utilized by all U.S. sites in conducting PHAs and Layers of Protection Analyses (LOPAs) and revised the corporate PHA Procedure to provide additional requirements when conducting PHA revalidations.  The team also established company-wide requirements for the timing and approval of resolutions to recommendations generated during PHAs and LOPAs.

Management of Change (MOC):  Members of SolutiaA?s PSCT, including our Process Safety Lead, volunteered to create an MOC Sub-Team to evaluate MOC practices and develop a set of minimum standards to provide a thorough and consistent approach for managing changes of all types within Solutia.  The team developed a common workflow and flowchart, drafted a specification for the evaluation and purchase of MOC software, evaluated 7 different electronic MOC packages through online demonstrations and webinars, and prepared and presented a recommendation for purchase to Solutia senior management.  

Contractor Safety:  Solutia and the Indian Orchard Plant began the implementation of a new contractor qualification program for all U.S. sites that utilizes a third party administrator, called BROWZ, to conduct thorough and consistent evaluation of contractors in accordance with SolutiaA?s requirements.  Training was provided to all of the siteA?s Contractor Management Representatives in 2008 and additional training is being conducted during 2009.

Safety Instrumented Systems:  The programs and practices for Safety Instrumented Systems, known as A?Instrumented Protective SystemsA? (IPSs) at the Indian Orchard Plant, continue to evolve and improve.  In 2008, the plantA?s E&I Technical Specialist was designated as the IPS issue owner for the site.  He has continued making progress in the conversion of the siteA?s existing interlock classifications to Solut

iaA?s newly-adopted integrity level system and several IPS reviews of existing systems have been conducted for our manufacturing processes during 2008 and 2009 thus far.  Our IPS issue owner is also a member of SolutiaA?s IPS Network, tasked with the development of company-wide standards and work practices related to instrumented systems and alarms.

As part of the IPS program, four different computer-based training (CBT) programs were deployed for site employees in 2008.  The content of each CBT was tailored to address the needs of a specific group of employees and their responsibilities related to IPS.  Each employeeA?s training requirements are based on job function, with more in-depth training required for those employees who are directly involved with production processes, such as operators, supervisors, electricians, and mechanics.  The four training programs developed include:  Instrumented Protective Systems Overview, Management Responsibilities for IPS, Operations Responsibilities, and Maintenance Responsibilities.  In addition, the siteA?s Process Safety Lead completed training on SolutiaA?s method for conducting Layers of Protection Analysis (LOPA) to facilitate the evaluation and classification of any new instrumented protective systems proposed for the plant operations.
